title: Winners Announced for Green Design Challenge 2026
author: Competition Committee
summary: Students from across Europe compete to design the most sustainable 3D-printed products. See the winning projects and innovative solutions.
content_markdown:
## Celebrating Innovation and Sustainability

After months of intense competition, we are proud to announce the winners of the **Edu-GArD3n Green Design Challenge 2026**. Over 120 students from 15 universities submitted their sustainable 3D printing projects.

## ðŸ¥‡ First Place: Solar-Powered Water Purifier

**Team**: GreenTech Innovators (TU Munich)  
**Students**: Anna Schmidt, Marco Bianchi, Lars Jensen

### Project Overview
A compact water purification system with 3D-printed components made from 100% recycled ocean plastic. The device uses solar energy and requires minimal maintenance.

**Innovation Highlights**:
- Self-cleaning filter mechanism
- Modular design for easy repair
- Purifies 10 liters per hour
- Production cost under â‚¬50

**Prize**: â‚¬3,000 + Featured presentation at final conference

---

## ðŸ¥ˆ Second Place: Adaptive Prosthetic Hand

**Team**: MedTech Solutions (University of Padova)  
**Students**: Sofia Greco, Ahmed Hassan

### Project Overview
A low-cost prosthetic hand designed for children, featuring biodegradable components that can be easily replaced as the child grows.

**Innovation Highlights**:
- Fully customizable sizing
- Grip strength sensors
- Biodegradable palm structure
- Total material cost under â‚¬30

**Prize**: â‚¬2,000 + Industry mentorship program

---

## ðŸ¥‰ Third Place: Urban Beehive System

**Team**: EcoArchitects (Aalto University)  
**Students**: Mika Virtanen, Katarina Novak

### Project Overview
Modular beehive components optimized for urban environments, printed using agricultural waste-based materials.

**Innovation Highlights**:
- Temperature-regulating design
- Easy inspection panels
- Stackable modules
- Bee-friendly surface textures

**Prize**: â‚¬1,000 + Exhibition at Green Week Brussels

---

## Honorable Mentions

- **Recycled Filament Extruder** - Delft University of Technology
- **Vertical Garden System** - Czech Technical University
- **Biodegradable Seed Planters** - University of Ljubljana

## Competition Impact

The challenge demonstrated that students can:
- Apply sustainability principles to real-world problems
- Collaborate across disciplines and borders
- Innovate within environmental constraints
- Create market-ready solutions

## Thank You

Special thanks to our jury members from industry and academia, and to all participating students who showed exceptional creativity and commitment to sustainability.

*All winning projects will be featured in the Edu-GArD3n project showcase and digital repository.*
